key_findings: GPT-4o achieves only 56% accuracy on multi-structured financial documents when processing PDFs directly, indicating significant challenges with complex document structures like nested tables and multi-dimensional plots.
Pre-processing tools significantly improve LLM performance, raising GPT-4o accuracy from 56% to 61.3% and GPT-4 accuracy to 76%, while also reducing overall processing costs.

Multi-modal Large Language Models (MLLMs) frequently produce hallucinations and erroneous outputs when interpreting intricately structured information in financial documents, highlighting the need for specialized preprocessing approaches.

Industrial and open-source preprocessing tools can be effectively integrated into a pipeline to enhance LLM comprehension of hybrid data sources including PDF documents and web pages with complex structures.

The research demonstrates that traditional text-based LLMs like GPT-4 can outperform newer multi-modal models like GPT-4o on structured financial document tasks when proper preprocessing is applied, suggesting preprocessing may be more critical than multi-modal capabilities for this domain.
limitations: Limited evaluation scope focusing primarily on financial documents may not generalize to other complex document types
Incomplete paper content provided limits understanding of specific preprocessing techniques and evaluation methodology
future_work: Further exploration of preprocessing pipeline optimization for different document types and structures

resource_requirements.compute_requirements: Access to GPT-4 and GPT-4o APIs

problem_addressed: Improving LLM accuracy on complex structured financial documents containing nested tables, plots, and multi-dimensional data that cause hallucinations and errors
